ygData.subject: Re: Q about new node innovations
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Rob, The solution to this problem is to look in the genome for a node ID that matches the newly created one. If such a node is present in the genome, then

Hi Rob,

The solution to this problem is to look in the genome for a node I=
D 
that matches the newly created one. If such a node is present in the 
ge=
nome, then just add new innovations like it is a novel one, 
othwerwise use=
 the existing innovation numbers/node ID.

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "Rob" <auto_phile@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> I've been looking at the=
 jneat code, specifically
> Genome.mutate_add_node, to try to understand ho=
w innovations work in
> this case. 
> 
> If the connection to add a new nod=
e to is A->B, we look through the
> list of innovations to see if there's a=
lready been a new node
> innovation for A->B, provided the innovation for A=
->B itself is the
> same as well.
> 
> If there's no matching innovation, t=
hen we can create a new node C,
> connection A->C->B, and create a new node=
 innovation.
> 
> However, if there is a matching innovation, then create a=
 node with
> the node ID from the innovation (call it C), and connect A->C-=
>B.
> 
> The issue that I see is that A->B still exists (whether enabled or=

> disabled). So if, in the same network that now contains A->C->B, the
> a=
lgorithm happens to choose A->B for a new node again, it is
> guaranteed to=
 find the innovation with new node C... and thus we 
would
> get two nodes =
with the same ID.
> 
> Is this the intended behavior, or am I reading this =
wrong?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> --Rob
>
